on the one hand, and also provides a good solution to the energy shortage problem.While TiO 2 -based semiconductor catalysts have been the most popular photocatalysts for this conversion, 28,29 interest in the exploration of novel photocatalysts with visible-light activity is increasing.Recently, we successfully prepared ultralong and ultrathin Zn 2 GeO 4 nanoribbons and found an unique 1D morphology, which greatly promotes the photocatalytic activity of the CO 2 reduction. 30n this paper, we synthesized,

out with 0.1 g zinc germanium oxynitride photocatalyst, which was uniformly placed at the bottom of a pyrex glass reactor with an area of 4.2 cm 2 .The reaction was in a gas-tight system, which was vacuum-treated several times, and followed by injection of high purity CO 2 gas into reaction system until ambient pressure was reached.0.4 mL of distilled water was injected into the system, which was filled with CO 2 to generate a water vapour.After adsorption of CO 2 equilibrium was reached in the dark, light

Please find the category of Light_source and Lamp from the provided context which describe an solar chemical experiment.
The generation condition of the extraction is given: If Light_source is Solar or Solar Simulator, Lamp is always Solar Simulator.
Please only select the generation from the provided possible choices.
Possible Choices:
Light_source: ['UV', 'Solar', 'UV-Vis', 'Monochromatic', 'Solar Simulator']
Lamp: ['Fluorescent', 'Mercury', 'Halogen', 'Mercury-Xenon', 'LED', 'Tungsten', 'Xenon', 'Tungsten-Halide', 'Solar Simulator']
Please generating restrictively follow the format, and must start the generation as the format. Do not generate anything else.
Light_source: XXX
Lamp: XXX

a calibration curve.The quantum yield was measured by inserting 420 nm band-pass filters in front of the reaction cell to supply irradiated light of wavelength of 420 AE 15 nm.No impure phases such as ZnO and GeO 2 were detected, although they appear in other solution methods. 15No diffraction peak were detected at low angle range, which indicates a pure inorganic phase of the resulting Zn 2 GeO 4 , rather than inorganic-En hybrids.

evidence.pdf_reference: out with 0.1 g zinc germanium oxynitride photocatalyst, which was uniformly placed at the bottom of a pyrex glass reactor with an area of 4.2 cm 2 .The reaction was in a gas-tight system, which was vacuum-treated several times, and followed by injection of high purity CO 2 gas into reaction system until ambient pressure was reached.0.4 mL of distilled water was injected into the system, which was filled with CO 2 to generate a water vapour.After adsorption of CO 2 equilibrium was reached in the dark, light

was reached in the dark, light photoirradiation was performed using a 300 W Xe arc lamp equipped with a UV cut-off filter (l 420 nm).A gas pump was used to accelerate gas diffusion.The volume of reaction system was 230 ml.The product was withdrawn with a gas-tight syringe (0.5 mL gas at one time) and detected by gas chromatography (Shimadzu, GC-14B with FID detector, Japan) during irradiation.Quantification of the CH 4 yield was based on the external standard and the use of a calibration curve.The quantum

the sum of the two individual co-catalysts.The yield of CH 4 reached a peak value at around 6 h, which may be due to absorption of the intermediate products on the photocatalyst surface to cover the active sites, these may then be reactivated with thermal treatment under vacuum.The quantum yield was calculated according to following equation: 45 in which N(CH 4 ) and N(Photons) signify the molecular number of generated CH 4 in unit time and the number of incident photons in unit time, respectively.The
